johnhanks

What is the logic in saying that a mutation is random if the environment induces it?

 Don't confuse randomness with probability. Exposing lung tissue to mutagens in cigarette smoke hugely increases the probability that a mutation will occur; but it does not make it necessary or inevitable. Which cell (if any) mutates, and when, are randomly determined.
 
 Also bear in mind that spontaneous mutations occur without environmental induction; and they do so at random.

pandion

look, nutballs......evolutionists have denied adaptive mutations for decades.
No. The first papers that suggested adaptive mutations were published about 2 decades ago. (CAIRNS, J., J. OVERBAUGH, and S. MILLER, 1988 The origin of mutants. Nature 335:142-145) But you don't seem to be aware of research since then, and in fact admissions by Cairns himself.
 
He's referring to directed mutations rather than adaptive mutations.
No. Actually he is correct. The term is not a reference to random mutations. It is the term used to refer to mutations that are a direct response by an organism to a changed environment. It does not refer to mutations that are acted upon by the environment and are thus adaptive.
 
Back in the 80s john Cairns used a strain of bacteria with a defect in the gene encoding an enzyme for breaking down lactose....this meant the bacteria could not live on lactose....but Cairns fed the bacteria lactose and looked for cells to appear that could live on it. He found the cells he was looking for, and interepreted this as the following:
 
 "suggesting that cells may have mechanisms for choosing which mutations will occur" 
Yeah. We all know about all of that. But really quite soon after the publication of his paper, even Cairns concluded that the mutational process was not "directed" toward specific targets (i.e., there was no reverse information flow) (FOSTER, P. L. and J. CAIRNS, 1992 Mechanisms of directed mutation. Genetics 131:783-789). Work has continued such that even after only 10 years it has shown that, "Although recent results show that the mutations that arise during selection are not "adaptive" in the original sense, the mutagenic mechanism that produces these mutations may...be of evolutionary significance." (FOster, P.L., 1998 Adaptive Mutation: Has the Unicorn Landed? Genetics, Vol. 148, 1453-1459)
 
This concept contradicted the dogma evolutionists had lived by up until that point, as it pointed towards lamarckism --
Indeed it did. But research since then, some of it by the very same researchers, has debunked Lamarckism once again. What is being observed in this case is a greatly increased production of Pol IV that is induced by a protein (sigma-38) that is produced by starving bacteria. Pol IV (Polymerase IV) is a mutation causing enzyme that causes errors in the copying of DNA. The researchers have concluded that what appears to be adaptive mutations is actually due to the fact that the other mutations are not apparent to researchers, since they result in the death of the bacteria either through starvation or because they are lethal.
 
and IDists do not claim these mutations are directed by "God" but from the interaction between the organism and the environment......and that the organism was set up to be adaptive to changing environments.
Actually, some IDists make that claim. You don't seem to be aware of the varied positions of IDists.

i·ro·ny (ī'rə-nē, ī'ər-)
 n., pl. -nies.
 [*][*] The use of words to express something different from and often opposite to their literal meaning.[*] An expression or utterance marked by a deliberate contrast between apparent and intended meaning.[*] A literary style employing such contrasts for humorous or rhetorical effect. See synonyms at wit1.[*] [*] Incongruity between what might be expected and what actually occurs: "Hyde noted the irony of Ireland's copying the nation she most hated" (Richard Kain).[*] An occurrence, result, or circumstance notable for such incongruity. See Usage Note at ironic.[*] Dramatic irony.[*] Socratic irony.
 [French ironie, from Old French, from Latin īrōnīa, from Greek eirōneia, feigned ignorance, from eirōn, dissembler, probably from eirein, to say.]Quoted from Answers.com.

It isn't claimed to be the TRUTH, but only the best explanation we can devise based on current evidence. In science, there is always the presumption that the explanation is tentative and subject to adjustment or rejection if new evidence comes to light.
